title: Harry Maguire dismisses difficult start to Man Utd career after record £80m transfer
text:

Harry Maguire says his world record £80million price tag is not a burden and has told Manchester United fans to judge him over time.

Maguire, who became the world's most expensive defender with his summer switch from Leicester , has endured a difficult start to his United career.

Ole Gunnar Solskjaer's side have won just two of their opening eight Premier League games and are down in 12 in the table, just two points off the relegation zone.

England defender Maguire missed a free header to give United the lead at Newcastle last weekend, Solskjaer's side eventually going down 1-0 to the struggling Toon, to pile the pressure on the Reds' boss.

But Maguire said now is not the time for short-term judgments and urged United fans to make an assessment of his own worth over a period of years, rather than on his first few games.

(Image: Getty Images)

(Image: EMPICS Sport)

"I think it's the long term, that's what the main thing is," said Maguire. "In five or six years' time, judge me then - whether I have been a success at this club or not.

"And I do believe and am really confident that, in five or six years’ time, I’ll be a success and I am sure we’ll have many, many good times here.

“We need to keep improving as a team, not just me as an individual. I feel, if we improve as a team, I'll be a success too.”

(Image: Getty Images)

Maguire also said he is not weighed down by the pressure of his fee, which saw him eclipse Liverpool's £75m signing Virgil van Dijk as the world's most expensive defender.

“It doesn't bother me at all," Maguire told Inside United. "It's something that I can't affect. Leicester wanted to keep me and they are in a great position as a club.

”Manchester United wanted to buy me and they came to an agreement. It's probably a good deal for both parties and it's something now where I want to concentrate on my football.”
description: Harry Maguire has urged United fans to judge him over time with Ole Gunnar Solskjaer's side struggling so far this term
